simplesect.title: NAME
simplesect.simpara: gitmailmap - Map author/committer names and/or E-Mail addresses

simplesect.title: DESCRIPTION
simplesect.simpara: If the file .mailmap exists at the toplevel of the repository, or at the location pointed to by the mailmap.file or mailmap.blob configuration options (see ), it is used to map author and committer names and email addresses to canonical real names and email addresses.

simplesect.title: SYNTAX
simplesect.simpara: The # character begins a comment to the end of line, blank lines are ignored.
In the simple form, each line in the file consists of the canonical real name of an author, whitespace, and an email address used in the commit (enclosed by < and >) to map to the name. For example:
which allows mailmap to replace only the email part of a commit, and:
which allows mailmap to replace both the name and the email of a commit matching the specified commit email address, and:
which allows mailmap to replace both the name and the email of a commit matching both the specified commit name and email address.
Both E-Mails and names are matched case-insensitively. For example this would also match the Commit Name <commit@email.xx> above:

simplesect.title: NOTES
simplesect.simpara: Git does not follow symbolic links when accessing a .mailmap file in the working tree. This keeps behavior consistent when the file is accessed from the index or a tree versus from the filesystem.

simplesect.title: EXAMPLES
simplesect.simpara: Your history contains commits by two authors, Jane and Joe, whose names appear in the repository under several forms:
simplesect.screen: Joe Developer <joe@example.com> Joe R. Developer <joe@example.com> Jane Doe <jane@example.com> Jane Doe <jane@laptop.(none)> Jane D. <jane@desktop.(none)>
simplesect.simpara: Now suppose that Joe wants his middle name initial used, and Jane prefers her family name fully spelled out. A .mailmap file to correct the names would look like:
simplesect.screen: Joe R. Developer <joe@example.com> Jane Doe <jane@example.com> Jane Doe <jane@desktop.(none)>
simplesect.simpara: Note that there's no need to map the name for <jane@laptop.(none)> to only correct the names. However, leaving the obviously broken <jane@laptop.(none)> and <jane@desktop.(none)> E-Mails as-is is usually not what you want. A .mailmap file which also corrects those is:
simplesect.screen: Joe R. Developer <joe@example.com> Jane Doe <jane@example.com> <jane@laptop.(none)> Jane Doe <jane@example.com> <jane@desktop.(none)>
simplesect.simpara: Finally, let's say that Joe and Jane shared an E-Mail address, but not a name, e.g. by having these two commits in the history generated by a bug reporting system. I.e. names appearing in history as:
A full .mailmap file which also handles those cases (an addition of two lines to the above example) would be:
simplesect.screen: Joe R. Developer <joe@example.com> Jane Doe <jane@example.com> <jane@laptop.(none)> Jane Doe <jane@example.com> <jane@desktop.(none)> Joe R. Developer <joe@example.com> Joe <bugs@example.com> Jane Doe <jane@example.com> Jane <bugs@example.com>
